metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Screening all pregnant women admitted to Labor and Delivery for the virus responsible for COVID-19

body_text.text: The COVID-19 pandemic sharply escalated in the United States in March and April of 24 2020. General medical and obstetric guidelines for managing suspected or positive COVID-19 25 patients mostly rely on maternal symptoms or close proximity to positive contacts to trigger 26 testing and subsequently diagnose COVID-19. 1 However, it has become apparent that most 27 cases of COVID-19 are the result of dissemination of the virus from asymptomatic individuals. 2 28

Persons who may unknowingly spread COVID-19 are often young and healthy, which fits the 29 demographic of many obstetric patients. Since medical staff are urged to conserve limited 30 personal protective equipment (PPE) for suspected or confirmed cases, 3 this increases the risk 31 of COVID-19 transmission to front-line health care workers from asymptomatic carriers. 32

Similarly, it increases the risk of COVID-19 transmission from mother to her infant or to other 33 obstetrical patients on a shared antepartum or postpartum unit. We propose, therefore, that were African-American, and 13.0% were Asian/Indian. 79
Of the 161 patients tested, 32 (19.9%) were COVID-19 positive and of these 11 (34%) 80 were symptomatic and 21 (66%) were asymptomatic (Table 1)

BIBREF7.title: Universal screening for SARS-CoV-2 in women 164 admitted for delivery

FIGREF0.text: 34 routine testing for COVID-19 should be performed in all obstetric patients admitted to Labor & 35 Delivery (L&D), regardless of maternal symptomatology, allowing for appropriate triage, 36 adequate obstetric and neonatal management, and safe patient transport within overcrowded 37 hospitals. 38 At the time of this writing, COVID-19 testing is recommended only for patients with 39 symptoms and those in close proximity to laboratory-confirmed positive patients. 4 The Society 40 of Maternal Fetal Medicine in conjunction with the Center for Disease Control and Prevention 41 advise not to prioritize testing of patients who are asymptomatic. 5 This may lead to 42 unrecognized viral spread and the incorrect use of PPE. 43 3 The primary objective of this study was to determine the accuracy of maternal 44 symptomatology in predicting the COVID-19 infection as confirmed by rapid laboratory testing. 45 Secondary objectives were the rate of neonatal COVID-19 infection as well as the impact of 46 routine maternal testing on the use of PPE as compared to its use based on symptoma retrospective cohort study of all obstetric patients admitted to L&D from 51 March 30 to April 12, 2020. Routine COVID-19 testing was implemented during this time period. 52 Testing was performed for all admitted patients, regardless of indication for admission or 53 presence of symptoms. IRB approval was obtained, as well as approval by a COVID-19 specific 54 research committee within our institution. The study was performed at NYU Winthrop Hospital 55 of the NYU Langone Health System; our hospital performs approximately 4,800 deliveries per 56 year. 57 All women were asked about symptoms (fever, cough, shortness of breath). The 58 presence of 1 or more of the aforementioned symptoms was used to determine if the patient 59 was symptomatic. Sampling was performed by a resident physician or physician assistant in 60 appropriate PPE using a nasal swab in a negative pressure room with closed doors. Each 61 nasopharyngeal swab was collected in the GeneXPert Nasopharyngeal Sample Collection Kit for 62 Viruses (Cepheid, Sunnyvale, CA) and transferred to the laboratory. Within the negative 63 pressure fume hood, 30 mL of viral culture media from the collection kit was transferred into 64 the Xpert Xpress SARS-CoV-2 cartridge (Cepheid, Sunnyvale, CA). The cartridge was 4 subsequently placed in Cepheid's equipment for polymerase chain reaction. 6 (Cepheid, 66 Sunnyvale, CA). The PCR test takes approximately 45 minutes. The result was scored as 67 "positive" or "negative." Viral testing was also performed in all neonates born to SARS-CoV-2 68 positive mothers. Results were used in clinical management to triage patients, guide PPE use, 69 and oversee the appropriate maternal/neonatal cohorting of patients. The accuracy of maternal 70 symptomatology to predict the COVID-19 infection was tested by constructing a 2x2table and 71calculating sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, negative predictive value, positive 72 likelihood ratio (sensitivity/1-specificity), and negative likelihood ratio (1-sensitivity/specificity)of 161 patients underwent routine COVID-19 testing on admission to L&D. Age 76 ranged 15 to 42 with a mean age of 31. There were 70 nulliparous women (43.4%) and 91 77 multiparous women (56.6%); 47.2% of women were Caucasian, 23.0% were Hispanic, 16.8% 78

FIGREF1.text: . The sensitivity, specificity, 81 positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of maternal symptoms to predict 82 COVID-19 infection were: 34.4% (11/32), 96.1% (124/129), 68.7% (11/16) and 85.5% (124/145), 83 respectively. The positive and negative likelihood ratios were 8.8 (34.4/3.9) and 0.68 84 (65.6/96.1), respectively. Twenty-nine neonates of COVID-19 positive mothers were tested and 85 they were all negative (3 results are pending at the time of this writing

TABREF0.text: In order to assess the impact of routine COVID-19 testing on PPE use, we hypothesized 87 that in our sample of 161 patients, 21 additional patients would have required PPE use, as 88 compared to a policy of screening based on maternal symptoms, since these 21 patients were 89 asymptomatic but tested positive for the virus. However, there were 5 patients who reported90 symptoms but tested negative for COVID-19; thus, PPE use could have been avoided in these 91 patient encounters. The overall impact in terms of PPE use with routine COVID-19 testing, as 92 compared to screening based only by maternal symptomatology, was an increase by 10% 93 (16/161). Out of 32 COVID-positive mothers, none of their neonates tested positive. 94 Comment: 96Table 1. Accuracy of maternal symptoms in predicting COVID-19 infection 174 (68.7%); negative predictive value=124/145 (85.5%) 177 Positive likelihood ratio=8.8; negative likelihood ration=0.68 178

back_matter.text: Twenty percent (32/161) of women admitted to L&D tested positive for Covid-19 97 infection; more importantly, almost two-thirds (66%) of COVID-19 positive women were 98 asymptomatic. All 29 neonates from COVID-19 positive mothers were negative. 99Routine testing for COVID-19 on admission to L&D resulted in an overall increase in the 100 use of PPE in approximately 10% of the cases. This, however, focused the use of PPE on the 101 right patient encounters. 102The results of our study have several important clinical implications. This approach 103 ensures that SARS-CoV-2 positive mothers are accurately identified and triaged. Clinicians can 104 monitor for the development of symptoms while these patients are admitted and allocate 105 inpatient resources appropriately (chest imaging, supplemental oxygen, infectious disease 106 consults) if a mother's respiratory status changes secondary to COVID-19.
